INTRODUCTION

Coded Gaze

‚Äúthe ways in which the priorities, preferences, and prejudicies of those who have power to shape technology can propagate harm, such as discrimination and erasure‚Äù (p. xiii)


Tip

Coded Gaze like ‚Äúmale gaze‚Äù or ‚Äúwhite gaze‚Äù or caste gaze.

Predictive AI Systems

‚Äúalready used to determine who gets a mortgage, who gets hired, who gets admitted to college, and who gets medical treatments‚Äù (p. xvi)

‚ÄúGiven the harm of AI, how can we center the lives of everyday people, and especially those at the margins, when we consider the designs and deployment of AI? Can we make room for the best of what AI has to offer while also resisting its perils?‚Äù (p. xvii)

Algorithmic Injustice

‚ÄúIf the AI systems ‚Ä¶ mask discrimination and systematize harmful bias, we entrench algorithmic injustice.‚Äù (p. xix)

‚Äúwhen machines fail, the people who often have the least resources and most limited access to power structures are those who have to experience the worst outcomes.‚Äù (p. xix)

AI Hypes

‚ÄúAI will no solve poverty ‚Ä¶ discrimination ‚Ä¶ climate change‚Äù (p. xix-xx)

‚Äúwe cannot use AI to sidestep the hard work of organising society ‚Ä¶ to sidestep conversations about patriarchy, white supremacy, ableism, or who hold power and who doesn‚Äôt.‚Äù (p. xx)

Author‚Äôs Concern & Hope

‚Äúhow technology can encode harmful discrimination and exclusionary practices.‚Äù (p. xx)

‚Äúdeeper understanding of why each and every one of us has a role to play in reaching toward algorithmic justice ‚Ä¶ you walk away with questions that push us all to rethink, reframe, and recode the future of AI.‚Äù (p. xxi)

Algorithmic Bias

‚Äúoccurs when one group is better served than another by an AI system. If you are denied employment because an AI system screened out candidates that attended women‚Äôs colleges, you have experienced algorithmic bias.‚Äù (p. 34.35)

Defaults are not Neutrals

‚ÄúMachines are presumed to be free from the societal biases that plague us mortals. My experiences were showing otherwise‚Äù (p. 42)


Personal Favs

  • ‚ÄúThe spotlight both shines and burns‚Äù (p. 42)

Defaults are not Neutrals

‚ÄúAccess to the training data is crucial when we want to have a deeper understanding of the risks posed by an AI system. Unless we know where the data comes from who colleted it, and how it is organized, we cannot know if ethical processes were used.‚Äù (p. 53)

‚ÄúWas the data obtained with consent? What were the working conditions and compensation for the workers who processed the data? These questions go beyong the technical.‚Äù (p. 53)

Defaults are not Neutrals

‚ÄúSimply because decisions are made by a computer analyzing data does not make them neutral‚Äù (p. 54)

‚ÄúThe coded gaze does not have to be explicit to do the job of oppression. Like systemic forms of oppression, including patriarchy and white supremacy, it is programmed into the fabric of society. Without intervention, those who have held power in the past continue to pass that power to those who are most like them.‚Äù (p. 55)

Face Recogniation Technologies

‚Äúinstead of saying a system uses facial recognition, a company might say‚Äùface matching‚Äù to distance themselves from scrutiny.‚Äù (p. 58)

AI Functionality Fallacy

the assumption that a system performs the task it was designed to execute as expected.‚Äù (p. 59)

Face Recogniation Technologies

‚Äúguess the emotions of a person ‚Ä¶ age estimation ‚Ä¶ gender classification ‚Ä¶ go as far as claiming that their systems can predict someone‚Äôs sexual orientation, political affiliation, intelligence or likelihood of committing a crime based solely on their facial features‚Äù (p. 60-61)

Face Recogniation Technologies

‚Äúfacial verification (one-to-one matching) and facial identification (one-to-many matching)‚Äù (p. 63)

Face Recogniation Technologies

‚ÄúWhen companies require individuals to fit a narrow definition of acceptable behaviour encoded into a machine learning model, they will reproduce harmful patterns of exclusion and suspicion.‚Äù (p. 66)

Guardians Assemble

‚ÄúImageNet showed that strategic data collection, often seen as grunt work and inferior to the development of algorithms, was just as important for advancing artificial intelligence. Data was queen.‚Äù (p. 69)


Tip

Team work, you will have to find your own team. You have believe in your cause and find people to get it done.

Power Shadows

‚Äúthe [LFW] database of images contained 77.5 percent male-labeled faces and 83.5 percent faces labeled white. The gold standard for facial recogniation, it turned out, was heavily skewed. I started calling these‚Äùpale male datasets‚Äù.‚Äù (p. 77)

‚Äúmachine learning community was not yet applying these insights from anti-discriminaiton scholarship.‚Äù (p. 80)

Power Shadows

‚Äúpeople underrepresented in the dataset. It would mean automated vehicles would be more likely to crash into some groups of people than others.‚Äù (p. 81)

‚ÄúPower shadows are cast when the biases or systemic exclusion of a society are reflected in the data.‚Äù (p. 83)

Power Shadows

‚ÄúIndia with its vast diversity of skin types has an entertainment and beauty industry that elevates light-skinned actors and actresses. ‚Ä¶ Beyond beauty, lighter skin is also associated with having more intelligence in societies touched by white supremacy.‚Äù (p. 84)

‚ÄúRelying on convenient data collection methods by collecting what is most popular and most readily available will reflect existing power structures.‚Äù (p. 85)
